message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) is more reliable than balanced accuracy, bookmaker informedness, and markedness in two-class confusion matrix evaluation
Paper Abstract: Abstract Evaluating binary classifications is a pivotal task in statistics and machine learning, because it can influence decisions in multiple areas, including for example prognosis or therapies of patients in critical conditions. The scientific community has not agreed on a general-purpose statistical indicator for evaluating two-class confusion matrices (having true positives, true negatives, false positives, and false negatives) yet, even if advantages of the Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) over accuracy and F 1 score have already been shown.In this manuscript, we reaffirm that MCC is a robust metric that summarizes the classifier performance in a single value, if positive and negative cases are of equal importance. We compare MCC to other metrics which value positive and negative cases equally: balanced accuracy (BA), bookmaker informedness (BM), and markedness (MK). We explain the mathematical relationships between MCC and these indicators, then show some use cases and a bioinformatics scenario where these metrics disagree and where MCC generates a more informative response.Additionally, we describe three exceptions where BM can be more appropriate: analyzing classifications where dataset prevalence is unrepresentative, comparing classifiers on different datasets, and assessing the random guessing level of a classifier. Except in these cases, we believe that MCC is the most informative among the single metrics discussed, and suggest it as standard measure for scientists of all fields. A Matthews correlation coefficient close to +1, in fact, means having high values for all the other confusion matrix metrics. The same cannot be said for balanced accuracy, markedness, bookmaker informedness, accuracy and F 1 score.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Confusion matrix"

Links: [{"title":"Confusion matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_matrix"},{"title":"Template talk:Confusion matrix terms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Confusion_matrix_terms"},{"title":"Matrix equivalence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_equivalence"},{"title":"Polynomial matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_matrix"},{"title":"Talk:Matrix management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Matrix_management"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about confusion matrices:

## Definition

A confusion matrix, also known as an error matrix, is a specific table layout that allows visualization of the performance of an algorithm, typically a supervised learning one.

## Structure and Components

The template for any binary confusion matrix uses four kinds of results: true positives, false negatives, false positives, and true negatives along with the positive and negative classifications.(no content)The four outcomes can be formulated in a 2×2 confusion matrix.

## Key Benefits

All correct predictions are located in the diagonal of the table, so it is easy to visually inspect the table for prediction errors, as values outside the diagonal will represent them.(no content)A confusion matrix allows more detailed analysis than simply observing the proportion of correct classifications (accuracy).

## Why It Matters

Accuracy will yield misleading results if the data set is unbalanced; that is, when the numbers of observations in different classes vary greatly. A confusion matrix helps address this issue by providing a more nuanced view of classifier performance.

## Extended Use

Confusion matrix is not limited to binary classification and can be used in multi-class classifiers as well.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Matthews correlation coefficient"

Links: [{"title":"Phi coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phi_coefficient"},{"title":"Talk:Matthews correlation coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Matthews_correlation_coefficient"},{"title":"Evaluation of binary classifiers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_of_binary_classifiers"},{"title":"P4-metric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P4-metric"},{"title":"Brian Matthews (biochemist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Matthews_(biochemist)"},{"title":"Correlation coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_coefficient"},{"title":"Correlation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation"},{"title":"Pearson correlation coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_correlation_coefficient"},{"title":"Mantel test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mantel_test"},{"title":"Covariance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covariance"}]

## Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC)

The Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) is used in machine learning as a measure of the quality of binary (two-class) classifications. It was coined in 1975 by biochemist Brian Matthews, though it is defined identically to the phi coefficient, introduced by Karl Pearson and also known as the Yule phi coefficient from its introduction by Udny Yule in 1912.

### Key Characteristics

The MCC is essentially a correlation coefficient between the observed and predicted binary classifications; it returns a value between −1 and +1, where a coefficient of +1 represents a perfect prediction, 0 no better than random prediction, and −1 indicates total disagreement between prediction and observation.

The coefficient accounts for true and false positives and negatives and is generally regarded as a balanced measure which can be used even if the classes are of very different sizes. The Matthews correlation coefficient is generally regarded as being one of the best measures for describing the confusion matrix of true and false positives and negatives by a single number.

### Advantages Over Other Metrics

The Matthews correlation coefficient is more informative than F1 score and accuracy in evaluating binary classification problems, because it takes into account the balance ratios of the four confusion matrix categories (true positives, true negatives, false positives, false negatives).

## Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC)

The Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) is used in machine learning as a measure of the quality of binary (two-class) classifications. It was coined in 1975 by biochemist Brian Matthews, though it is defined identically to the phi coefficient, introduced by Karl Pearson and also known as the Yule phi coefficient from its introduction by Udny Yule in 1912.

### Key Characteristics

The MCC is essentially a correlation coefficient between the observed and predicted binary classifications; it returns a value between −1 and +1, where a coefficient of +1 represents a perfect prediction, 0 no better than random prediction, and −1 indicates total disagreement between prediction and observation.

The coefficient accounts for true and false positives and negatives and is generally regarded as a balanced measure which can be used even if the classes are of very different sizes. The Matthews correlation coefficient is generally regarded as being one of the best measures for describing the confusion matrix of true and false positives and negatives by a single number.

### Advantages Over Other Metrics

The Matthews correlation coefficient is more informative than F1 score and accuracy in evaluating binary classification problems, because it takes into account the balance ratios of the four confusion matrix categories (true positives, true negatives, false positives, false negatives).

Based on the web search results, here's what you need to know about binary classification:

## Definition

Binary classification is the task of putting things into one of two categories (each called a class).(no content)It is the simplest form of the general task of classification into any number of classes.

## Machine Learning Context

Statistical classification is a problem studied in machine learning in which the classification is performed on the basis of a classification rule. It is a type of supervised learning, a method of machine learning where the categories are predefined, and is used to categorize new probabilistic observations into said categories. When there are only two categories the problem is known as statistical binary classification.

## Common Applications

Common binary classification tasks include medical testing to determine patient conditions, spam detection in emails, and disease diagnosis assessments.

## Evaluation Metrics

Given a classification of a specific data set, there are four basic combinations of actual data category and assigned category: true positives TP (correct positive assignments), true negatives TN (correct negative assignments), false positives FP (incorrect positive assignments), and false negatives FN (incorrect negative assignments).(no content)In medicine sensitivity and specificity are often used, while in computer science precision and recall are preferred.

## Common Algorithms

Logistic regression is a supervised machine learning algorithm widely used for binary classification tasks, such as identifying whether an email is spam or not and diagnosing diseases by assessing the presence or absence of specific conditions based on patient test results.

## Balanced Accuracy in Machine Learning

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about balanced accuracy:

### Definition

Balanced accuracy (bACC) normalizes true positive and true negative predictions by the number of positive and negative samples, respectively, and divides their sum by two.

### Use Case and Importance

Balanced accuracy is particularly useful for addressing issues with imbalanced datasets. Accuracy will yield misleading results if the data set is unbalanced; that is, when the numbers of observations in different classes vary greatly. 

For example, for a dataset with 95 negative and 5 positive samples, classifying all as negative gives 0.5 balanced accuracy rather than the 95% accuracy that standard accuracy would report, which better reflects the classifier's actual performance on both classes.

### Advantages Over Other Metrics

Balanced accuracy offers advantages over standard accuracy and even the F1 score. A classifier might achieve 100% recognition rate for the majority class but 0% for the minority class, while the F1 score is even more unreliable in such cases and would yield over 97.4%, whereas informedness removes such bias.

This makes balanced accuracy a more honest assessment of classifier performance when dealing with class imbalance, ensuring that poor performance on minority classes isn't masked by high overall accuracy.

Links: [{"title":"Precision and recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_and_recall"},{"title":"Accuracy paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accuracy_paradox"},{"title":"Evaluation of binary classifiers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_of_binary_classifiers"},{"title":"F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score"},{"title":"Accuracy and precision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accuracy_and_precision"},{"title":"Template:Machine learning evaluation metrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Machine_learning_evaluation_metrics"},{"title":"Fairness (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Confusion matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matching_matrix"},{"title":"Mean average precision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Mean_average_precision&redirect=no"},{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the accuracy metric in machine learning:

## Definition

Accuracy measures the fraction of all instances that are correctly categorized; it is the ratio of the number of correct classifications to the total number of correct or incorrect classifications: (TP + TN)/total population = (TP + TN)/(TP + TN + FP + FN).(no content)When computing accuracy in multiclass classification, accuracy is simply the fraction of correct classifications. For example, if a classifier makes ten predictions and nine of them are correct, the accuracy is 90%.

## Limitations

While simple to understand, accuracy has significant limitations. Accuracy can be a misleading metric for imbalanced data sets. For instance, classifying all values as negative in a dataset with 95 negative and 5 positive values gives 0.95 accuracy score.(no content)The accuracy paradox is the paradoxical finding that accuracy is not a good metric for predictive models when classifying in predictive analytics because a simple model may have a high level of accuracy but too crude to be useful.

## Alternative Metrics

In medicine sensitivity and specificity are often used, while in computer science precision and recall are preferred.(no content)Balanced accuracy normalizes true positive and true negative predictions by the number of positive and negative samples, respectively, and can serve as an overall performance metric for a model, whether or not the true labels are imbalanced in the data.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about bookmaker statistics and informedness in a statistical context.

The search results reveal that "informedness" is a statistical metric rather than a direct measure of bookmaker knowledge. Informedness is the probability of an informed decision (as opposed to a random guess) and takes into account all predictions. This metric is also known as Youden's J statistic (informedness or Δp′).

In the context of performance evaluation, informedness removes bias and yields 0 as the probability of an informed decision for any form of guessing, making it useful for assessing classifier performance.

Regarding bookmaker statistics more broadly, the search results do contain information about bookmaker margins. A study of six large bookmakers between the 2005/06 season and 2017/2018 season showed that average margin in Premier League decreased from 9% to 4%, in English Football League Championship, English Football League One, and English Football League Two from 11% to 6%, and in National League from 11% to 8%.

If you were looking for different or more specific information about bookmaker operations or statistics, please let me know and I can search with a more targeted query.

Web search results for query: "F1 score"

Links: [{"title":"F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score"},{"title":"Talk:F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:F1_Score"},{"title":"Precision and recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_and_recall"},{"title":"Piotroski F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piotroski_F-Score"},{"title":"Aston Martin in Formula One - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aston_Martin_F1_Team"},{"title":"Phi coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthews_correlation_coefficient"},{"title":"List of Formula One World Championship points scoring systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Championship_points_scoring_systems"},{"title":"Stewart SF02 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stewart_SF02"},{"title":"Tyrrell 023 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrrell_023"},{"title":"Sauber C30 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauber_C30"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the F1 score:

## Definition
The F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall. More specifically, it is calculated as 2 times (precision × recall) divided by (precision + recall).

## Applications
The F-score is often used in the field of information retrieval for measuring search, document classification, and query classification performance, and is particularly relevant in applications which are primarily concerned with the positive class and where the positive class is rare relative to the negative class. The F-score has been widely used in the natural language processing literature, such as in the evaluation of named entity recognition and word segmentation.

## Multi-class Applications
The F-score is also used for evaluating classification problems with more than two classes (multiclass classification), with a common method being to average the F-score over each class, aiming at a balanced measurement of performance.

## Criticisms
David Hand and others criticize the widespread use of the F1 score since it gives equal importance to precision and recall, and in practice, different types of mis-classifications incur different costs. Additionally, F1 has a lack of symmetry, meaning it may change its value when dataset labeling is changed—when "positive" samples are named "negative" and vice versa.

Web search results for query: "Markedness statistics"

Links: [{"title":"Markedness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markedness"},{"title":"Markedness model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markedness_model"},{"title":"Phi coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phi_coefficient"},{"title":"Youden's J statistic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youden's_J_statistic"},{"title":"Optimality theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimality_theory"},{"title":"Marker (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_marker"},{"title":"Markov property - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_property"},{"title":"Marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marking"},{"title":"Marked (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marked_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Ferdinand de Saussure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_de_Saussure"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about markedness statistics:

## Overview

Markedness statistics refers to multiple related concepts depending on the field:

### In Psychology and Statistics

In psychology, markedness is quantified as a measure of how much one variable is marked as a predictor or possible cause of another, and is also known as Δp (deltaP) in simple two-choice cases.(no content)The component regression coefficients of the Matthews correlation coefficient are markedness (Δp) and Youden's J statistic (informedness or Δp′), which correspond to different directions of information flow.

### In Linguistics

In linguistics and social sciences, markedness is the state of standing out as nontypical or divergent as opposed to regular or common.(no content)In a marked–unmarked relation, one term of an opposition is the broader, dominant one, where the dominant default or minimum-effort form is known as unmarked and the other, secondary one is marked.

### In Sociolinguistics

The markedness model proposed by Carol Myers-Scotton is one account of the social indexical motivation for code-switching, holding that speakers use language choices to index rights and obligations sets, the abstract social codes in operation between participants in a given interaction.

These different applications of markedness statistics reflect how the concept is used across various disciplines to measure asymmetries, predict causation, and understand linguistic and social patterns.

In psychology, markedness is quantified as a measure of how much one variable is marked as a predictor or possible cause of another, and is also known as Δp (deltaP) in simple two-choice cases.(no content)The component regression coefficients of the Matthews correlation coefficient are markedness (Δp) and Youden's J statistic (informedness or Δp′), which correspond to different directions of information flow.

### In Linguistics

In linguistics and social sciences, markedness is the state of standing out as nontypical or divergent as opposed to regular or common.(no content)In a marked–unmarked relation, one term of an opposition is the broader, dominant one, where the dominant default or minimum-effort form is known as unmarked and the other, secondary one is marked.

### In Sociolinguistics

The markedness model proposed by Carol Myers-Scotton is one account of the social indexical motivation for code-switching, holding that speakers use language choices to index rights and obligations sets, the abstract social codes in operation between participants in a given interaction.

These different applications of markedness statistics reflect how the concept is used across various disciplines to measure asymmetries, predict causation, and understand linguistic and social patterns.
